docs.lead_paragraph: A campaign to require condom use in pornographic film productions in California has submitted enough signatures to election officials before Monday's deadline to put a ballot measure before state voters in 2016, organizers said.

headline.main: Activists Submit Signatures for California Condoms-In-Porn Vote
headline.print_headline: Activists Submit Signatures for California Condoms-In-Porn Vote

docs.snippet: A campaign to require condom use in pornographic film productions in California has submitted enough signatures to election officials before Monday's deadline to put a ballot measure before state voters in 2016, organizers said.

docs.lead_paragraph: A Colorado woman whose unborn baby was cut from her womb says she feels compassion for the woman facing charges in the case and says she hasn't lost faith in humanity.

headline.main: Woman Who Had Baby Cut From Womb Feels Compassion
headline.print_headline: Woman Who Had Baby Cut From Womb Feels Compassion

docs.snippet: A Colorado woman whose unborn baby was cut from her womb says she feels compassion for the woman facing charges in the case and says she hasn't lost faith in humanity.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chemical giant DuPont Monday will face the first trial in litigation from residents near one of its plants in West Virginia who have accused the company of sickening them by emitting a toxic chemical that leaked into their drinking water.

headline.main: DuPont to Face First Trial Over C-8 Exposure
headline.print_headline: DuPont to Face First Trial Over C-8 Exposure

docs.snippet: Chemical giant DuPont Monday will face the first trial in litigation from residents near one of its plants in West Virginia who have accused the company of sickening them by emitting a toxic chemical that leaked into their drinking water.

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, doctors swore by the symptoms of head trauma that were accepted as evidence of a crime against a child. Now, a growing number are not so sure.

headline.main: Shaken Baby Syndrome: A Diagnosis That Divides the Medical World

docs.snippet: For years, doctors swore by the symptoms of head trauma that were accepted as evidence of a crime against a child. Now, a growing number are not so sure.

docs.lead_paragraph: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, September 13, 2015.
docs.snippet: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, September 13, 2015.

docs.lead_paragraph: PLUNKETT--Caryl D. Faith, family, friends: These were the cornerstones of the life of Caryl Donnelly Plunkett. A generous and devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many, Caryl passed away peacefully on September 9th, 2015 surrounded by her family. Caryl was a ray of light and a beacon of strength and energy. She lived each day to its fullest, even as she fought cancer these last ten years. Originally from Plantsville, CT, Caryl graduated from Marymount College in Tarrytown, New York. She returned to Tarrytown soon after graduation when she married William F. Plunkett Jr. and stayed for 48 years to raise their six children. She was an accomplished businesswoman, public servant and active charitable volunteer. She has been honored on several occasions for her accomplishments and good works. Marymount College awarded Caryl both the Gloria Gaines and Golden Dome awards, the highest awards bestowed on alumnae, for her years of service to the College. Caryl was a Dame in the Sovereign Order of Malta and a member of the Patron of the Arts of the Vatican Museum. She served as Chairwoman of the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Village of Tarrytown, a member of the Pregnancy Care Center of Westchester, a volunteer at Maria Fareri Children's Hospital Foundation, and a Board Member of AMIC Clearview School. In 2006, she was appointed by the Governor as Honorary Chair of the New York State Observance of United Nations Day. Always known for her quick wit and generous spirit, she was elegant, fun loving and active. She was a gracious hostess and joyful friend and colleague. More importantly, she selflessly gave her love and humor to all she came into contact with. She was happiest spending time with her family at Bantam Lake, CT or on the beach in Kiawah Island, SC. Caryl, born in 1941, is survived by her husband, Bill, their six children Ryan Plunkett, John Brendan (Jake) Plunkett, Erin Plunkett Niehaus, Kathleen Plunkett O'Connor, Timothy Plunkett, Patrick Plunkett and their spouses, and nineteen grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St Patrick's Cathedral at 1:30pm Monday September 14th. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Caryl Plunkett HOPE in Lung Cancer fund at at Martin Health Foundation, 2135 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL 34996 or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in honor of Caryl Plunkett. 1/3

headline.main: ‘Black Man in a White Coat,’ by Damon Tweedy

docs.abstract: Carl L Hart reviews memoir Black Man in a White Coat: A Doctor's Reflections on Race and Medicine by Damon Tweedy.
docs.snippet: A look at the challenges and realities facing black doctors and patients.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidate is gone, and there may not be another chance to point out the names of his right boot and left boot.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column bids farewell to Texas Gov Rick Perry, who is dropping out of Republican presidential nomination contest; recalls some of memorable moments from this and his previous presidential campaign.
docs.snippet: The Republican presidential candidate is gone, and there may not be another chance to point out the names of his right boot and left boot.

docs.lead_paragraph:
PLUNKETT--Caryl D.

Faith, family, friends: These were the cornerstones of the life of Caryl Donnelly Plunkett. A generous and devoted wife, mother, aunt, grandmother and friend to many, Caryl passed away peacefully on September 9th, 2015 surrounded by her family. Caryl was a ray of light and a beacon of strength and energy. She lived each day to its fullest, even as she fought cancer these last ten years. Originally from Plantsville, CT, Caryl graduated from Marymount College in Tarrytown, New York. She returned to Tarrytown soon after graduation when she married William F. Plunkett Jr. and stayed for 48 years to raise their six children. She was an accomplished businesswoman, public servant and active charitable volunteer. She has been honored on several occasions for her accomplishments and good works. Marymount College awarded Caryl both the Gloria Gaines and Golden Dome awards, the highest awards bestowed on alumnae, for her years of service to the College. Caryl was a Dame in the Sovereign Order of Malta and a member of the Patron of the Arts of the Vatican Museum. She served as Chairwoman of the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Village of Tarrytown, a member of the Pregnancy Care Center of Westchester, a volunteer at Maria Fareri Children's Hospital Foundation, and a Board Member of AMIC Clearview School. In 2006, she was appointed by the Governor as Honorary Chair of the New York State Observance of United Nations Day. Always known for her quick wit and generous spirit, she was elegant, fun loving and active. She was a gracious hostess and joyful friend and colleague. More importantly, she selflessly gave her love and humor to all she came into contact with. She was happiest spending time with her family at Bantam Lake, CT or on the beach in Kiawah Island, SC. Caryl, born in 1941, is survived by her husband, Bill, their six children Ryan Plunkett, John Brendan (Jake) Plunkett, Erin Plunkett Niehaus, Kathleen Plunkett O'Connor, Timothy Plunkett, Patrick Plunkett and their spouses, and nineteen grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St Patrick's Cathedral at 1:30pm Monday September 14th. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Caryl Plunkett HOPE in Lung Cancer fund at at Martin Health Foundation, 2135 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL 34996 or Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in honor of Caryl Plunkett.
